title.value: PENALTIES AND REWARDS FOR FAIR LEARNING IN PAIRED KIDNEY EXCHANGE PROGRAMS
title.justification: This is the title given at the beginning of the research paper.
title.quote: PENALTIES AND REWARDS FOR FAIR LEARNING IN PAIRED KIDNEY EXCHANGE PROGRAMS

extractions.description: This paper studies the use of dynamic learning algorithms in kidney exchange programs (KEPs) to improve the efficiency and fairness of kidney transplants. Focusing on the Canadian Kidney Paired Donation Program, it demonstrates that dynamically learning patient-donor weights can lead to better outcomes in terms of number of transplants, waiting times, and fairness across different patient groups.

type.justification: The paper involves experiments using simulations of kidney exchange programs to assess the performance of different learning algorithms.
type.quote: We confirm this hypothesis using a full scale simulation of the Canadian Kidney Paired Donation Program: learning algorithms, that attempt to learn optimal patient-donor weights in advance via dynamic simulations, do lead to improved outcomes.

name.justification: The main focus of the paper is on improving kidney exchange programs, which is a healthcare-related application.
name.quote: A kidney exchange program, also called a kidney paired donation program, can be viewed as a repeated, dynamic trading and allocation mechanism.

name.justification: The paper applies optimization techniques to improve outcomes in kidney exchange programs.
name.quote: The general approach for transplant selection is to add a weight wi to each node i or a weight wij to each arc (i, j) in the graph.

name.justification: The core of the paper involves dynamic learning algorithms to determine optimal weights for patient-donor pairs.
name.quote: Our key finding is that a judicious choice of weights can simultaneously improve performance with respect to multiple criteria including group fairness, waiting times, and the number of transplants. However, this conclusion requires that negative weights (penalties) are permitted in transplant selection, in addition to positive weights (rewards).

name.value: Dynamic Learning Algorithm for Fairness in Kidney Exchange
name.justification: The paper contributes a dynamic learning algorithm aimed at optimizing fairness and efficiency in kidney exchange programs.
name.quote: In particular, our learning algorithms, designed with the objective of fairness (that is, equity in terms of transplant accessibility across cPRA groups), also lead to an increased number of transplants and shorter average waiting times.

is_contributed.justification: The dynamic learning algorithm is a key contribution of this paper.
is_contributed.quote: In particular, our learning algorithms, designed with the objective of fairness (that is, equity in terms of transplant accessibility across cPRA groups), also lead to an increased number of transplants and shorter average waiting times.

is_executed.justification: Simulations were run to test the proposed dynamic learning algorithm.
is_executed.quote: We confirm this hypothesis using a full-scale simulation of the Canadian Kidney Paired Donation Program: learning algorithms, that attempt to learn optimal patient-donor weights in advance via dynamic simulations, do lead to improved outcomes.

is_compared.justification: The learning algorithms are compared against the myopic algorithm and the Canadian KPD algorithm.
is_compared.quote: All of our learning algorithms significantly outperform the myopic algorithm and the Canadian KPD algorithm; see Table 5.1.

referenced_paper_title.value: Futurematch: Combining Human Value Judgments and Machine Learning to Match in Dynamic Environments
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced paper for the learning algorithm used in the context of kidney exchange programs.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Futurematch: Combining Human Value Judgments and Machine Learning to Match in Dynamic Environments

name.value: Canadian Kidney Paired Donation Program Data
name.justification: The simulation data is taken from the Canadian Kidney Paired Donation Program.
name.quote: Specifically, our learning algorithms, designed with the objective of fairness (that is, equity in terms of transplant accessibility across cPRA groups), also lead to an increased number of transplants and shorter average waiting times.

referenced_paper_title.value: Interprovincial Organ Sharing National Data Report: Kidney Paired Donation Program 2009-2018
referenced_paper_title.justification: The referenced data comes from a report on the Canadian Kidney Paired Donation Program.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Canadian Blood Services. Interprovincial organ sharing national data report: Kidney paired donation program 2009-2018. https://professionaleducation.blood.ca/sites/default/files/kpd-eng_2018.pdf, 2018.

name.justification: The simulations were implemented using Python.
name.quote: The model, described in Section 2, was implemented using Python 3.

referenced_paper_title.justification: Python is a programming language and not a research paper, thus it does not have a referenced paper title.
referenced_paper_title.quote: The model, described in Section 2, was implemented using Python 3.
